posts.name: Rocky Xu
posts.cooked: Hey Allen! Thanks for the quick reply! I see the cable you recommended is the unshielded type. Have you guys ever considered using a shielded one instead? The one you pointed out is super easy to find here, making it really tempting!

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: Some background, I work in Enterprise IT and Network Engineering. CAT 5e is perfectly suitable for FRC. You do not need CAT 6 or CAT6a. There is nothing really on an FRC robot that would require shielded Ethernet, its more important to keep your robot radio high up and away from motors than it is any cables. Typical rule of thumb is to use COTS Ethernet unless you have a specific need that requires making your own. Side note, you should not need to glue your Ethernet cables, if a cable is not staying seated, it should be replaced.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked: The one we've used before tends to break when the robot accelerates too quickly and pulls on the end considered heavy-duty. We've needed to replace it for the upcoming season, indicating it's an investment to protect against such issues. Generally, it performs well during normal use, except when spooling or unspooling, which isn't much different from other non-spooled cables. To address potential problems during tugs-of-war with the robot, coupling a mini-retractor to the unspooled end could deploy enough cable to prevent damage. For practice fields allowing dynamic movements, being cautious with cable usage is advised, especially since many are station-focused and disallow such activities. We typically avoid these situations until places like DCMPs or Worlds where larger facilities are available.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked: We bought the same branded product, and I concur, it became flaky initially and later failed completely; it was a significant waste of money.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked: It is advisable against crimping your own cables. While this is a valuable skill, it can lead to unexpected issues—for instance, a cable that functions well for data transmission might fail due to problems with the PoE pins. In addition, teaching students how to coil wire using techniques like overhand and underhand is beneficial and should be emphasized, as these methods ensure proper wiring and reliability. However, focus primarily on the aspects most critical to the operation of the robot itself.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Importantly, flat Ethernet cables are usually stranded, making them more durable and suitable for long-term use. Solid-core cables tend to wear out relatively quickly compared to stranded ones.

posts.name: Ryan Reed
posts.cooked:
We crimp our own Ethernet cables on our robot. I believe it’s crucial to use stranded cables and a robust boot to prevent fatigue. If the boot makes releasing the cable challenging, trimming the part covering the release without affecting strain relief is advisable. We utilize 28AWG cables and connectors from InfiniteCables. I prefer their style over others where individual wires protrude, as it minimizes the risk of shorts and simplifies assembly by feeding wires through the insert before trimming and inserting into the connector.

This cable style eliminates protruding wires, reducing the chance of shorts and streamlining assembly. The price is $81.78 for the cable and $11.41 for the RJ45 plug, along with a $4.00 boot. These components ensure reliable performance. Additionally, we can label cables with heat shrink labels using a compatible label maker, such as the Brother P-Touch series, to clearly indicate connected devices.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: Are the Slim Run cables at 30 or 32 AWG mentioned in this thread legal to use on a robot? R622 states that signal level cables need to be at least 28 AWG. Are Ethernet cables not considered signal level cables?

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: The table on FRCManual.com indicates that certain PWM ports require Cat5e-8 cables alongside 26 AWG ((27 SWG or 0.14 mm²)) wires near ROBO RIO, whereas other areas list only 28 AWG ((29 SWG or 0.08 mm²)). This leaves ambiguity regarding whether the CAT wires can be sized smaller than 28 AWG, especially concerning their use in PWM or <1A circuits, which must be fully copper. It is clear that the right side of the table does not represent a strict AND relationship, as not all PWM outputs require Cat cables. However, determining whether it represents a strict OR condition—that CAT cables can bypass wire gauge requirements—is unclear.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
A COTS Commercial off-the-shelf Cat5e cable was modified for the RoboRIOv2 to Vivid Radio link, eliminating the use of Blue and brown power lines.

One student discovered an effective method to label cables using 18mm Brother label tapes, replicating the appearance of Panduit label machine labels. This approach allowed for consistent labeling across various wire bundle sizes, improving readability through repeated text design. These wide-label tapes were easier to source than traditional heat shrink tubes, enabling comprehensive cable and wire pairing labeling for the 2025 robot.

What advantage does this give you? From R703: Use specific Ethernet port for roboRIO. The roboRIO Ethernet port must be connected to either the port labeled “RIO” of a VH-109 radio via (either directly, or via a Cat5 Ethernet pigtail) an RPM, passive PoE injector cable or adapter (whether or not it is used to power the radio), or an Ethernet cable with the appropriate wires removed on the roboRIO end. All wires or adapters used must be fully insulated.
